vectorData.altText: That’s right!  Structure A is the internal capsule. This is formed as fibres of the corona radiata condense deep to the putamen.
That is incorrect. Click here      to learn the answer, then come back to try again.
L. cerebral hemisphere, horizontal section. From Serial Dissections of the Human Brain, by Carlton G. Smith, M.D., Ph.D., © 1981 by Gage.

capsule to expose the lateral surface of the putamen. Note how the fibres of the corona radiata are now disappearing deep to the putamen. In doing so, they form the internal capsule. You will recognize the putamen by its more homogeneous texture, as compared to the fibrous appearance of the external capsule.
DISSECTING from lateral to medial, remove the fibers of the external

R. cerebral hemisphere, lateral  view, deepest dissection.
From Serial Dissections of the Human Brain, by Carlton G. Smith, M.D., Ph.D., © 1981 by Gage.
The optic radiation consists of axons relaying information from the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus to the visual cortex of the occipital lobe.
